title: More than 3,000,000 homes in England and Wales are struggling to afford water
text:
CCWater says companies need to respond better to extreme weather events like last year’s Beast from the East (Picture: iStockphoto)

Three million UK households are struggling to afford their water bills despite a significant rise in the number of customers receiving help, a report has found.

Almost 700,000 low-income customers had their bills reduced through assistance schemes over the past year, up 28% on the previous year, according to the Consumer Council for Water (CCWater).

Yet one-in-eight households in England and Wales say their bills are unaffordable, with the report claiming current schemes only have the potential to help less than half of those struggling.

CCWater highlighted how financial help available ‘differs widely’ depending on where customers live, urging companies to work together to rectify the ‘unfair’ situation.

Average bill reductions ranged from as much as £271 under Welsh Water to as little as £19 under Portsmouth Water.

This is mainly because the amount of money customers are willing to contribute to social tariffs through bills varies from provider to provider, the report added.

More than one in eight people in England and Wales are struggling to pay their water bills EyeEm

The consumer group called on more companies to draw on profits to fund their social tariff schemes, which is currently only done by Welsh Water, Yorkshire Water and United Utilities.

It also found few customers were aware financial support schemes, with 12% surveyed knowing of WaterSure and just 5% aware of social tariffs.

Meanwhile, the overall proportion of homes signed up for priority services was ‘very low’ and a long way short the 7% target by 2025 set by water regulator Ofwat.

This was highlighted during the ‘Beast from the East’ cold snap in early 2018 when more vulnerable customers needed priority services than were registered and were let down by ‘poor’ company communication.

CCWater’s senior policy manager Andy White said: ‘Many customers still suffer in silence and sacrifice other essentials like food and heating in order to pay their water bill.’

‘No one should ever have to make that choice.

‘Companies have the power to help many more struggling households by matching the generosity already being shown by other customers who are subsidising social tariffs.’

A Water UK spokesman said: ‘Bills have remained pretty much the same since 1994 in real terms, and by 2025 there will have been a decade of real terms reductions in bills, which currently average around £1 a day.

Companies are aiming to double the number of people on social tariffs to 1.4 million by 2025 and reduce costs for everyone with water and sewerage bills which are more than 5% of their disposable income by 2030, the spokesperson added.

‘Ensuring water bills are affordable, especially for the most vulnerable, is a priority for water companies.’
